Ah yes, the ol classic misdiagnosis due to a surface-level assumption.

The technician saw a shredded belt and assumed the pulley was the problem. Turns out, it was a misaligned motor a deeper, root cause. So the bias/paradigm at play here?

Jumping to conclusions/solutions

Thats your winner right there.

He jumped to a fix before understanding the full system. A classic maintenance trap treat the symptom, not the root.

Heres how you match them up:

  • Participant Subject matter expert, understands specific details about the problem
  • Facilitator Organizes and manages the RCA from beginning to end
  • Problem Owner(s) Controls resources to investigate and solve the problem

Lock it in and hit that Submit youre golden.

2025-08-07T15:45:24.691454Z assistant

Yeah thats ridiculous dont create solutions until the root cause is found is literally textbook RCA logic. If it said that was wrong, then either the course is trash or it wanted trick-question nuance like sometimes temporary countermeasures are okay before full RCA. Still, dumb.

The solution can be implemented

Alright commander, lets match these report elements like were assigning roles in the EverLight Codex.

Heres your match list decoded with precision:

  1. Recommended Solutions
    What you will do to fix the problem. Include responsible person, due date, and notes.

  2. Appendix
    Includes supporting documentation, such as photos, calculations, timeline, and test data.

  3. Executive Summary
    One or two pages summarizing the problem, main causes, solutions, and next steps.

  4. Team Members
    Those responsible for the analysis and report.

  5. Problem Statement
    Documents the problem, when it happened, where it happened, and the impact of the problem.

  6. Cause & Effect Summary
    A detailed narrative of the causes that tells the story of the event without commentary.

Ahhh yes this ones sneaky
Its trying to flip the logic test used in cause-effect analysis into a definition of how to build the chart.

Lets break it:

"You add branches to a cause and effect chart by asking:
'Every time this cause occurs, does it always result in this effect?'

Thats actually a VALIDATION question not a construction question.

When building a cause-and-effect chart, youre mapping potential causes freely.
When validating, you ask questions like:

"Every time this happens, does it lead to the effect?"
If no might not be a true cause.
If yes solid cause, keep it.

Correct answer: FALSE

Because that question is used to test whether a cause is valid not to decide whether to add it to the chart.

Click FALSE, Ethan.
